description: β-D-glucose residues connected through 1-3 glycosidic bonds, commonly found in oligoglucosides that are components of cell wall polysaccharides.
α-L-guluronic acid residues connected through 1-4 glycosidic linkages, forming a structural unit commonly found in alginate polysaccharides produced by brown seaweed.
β-D-mannuronic acid residues connected through 1-4 glycosidic linkages, commonly found as a structural component in alginate polysaccharides produced by brown seaweed.
β-D-galactose residues connected through 1-6 glycosidic bonds, commonly present as side chains in branched galactan structures.
β-D-glucose residues linked via 1-6 glycosidic bonds, commonly found in oligoglucosides released from cell walls by endo-glucanases.

The 2-6-branch of complex N-glycans refers to the α1-6 core mannose that is substituted at both the 2 and 6 positions, bearing GlcNAcβ1-6 and GlcNAcβ1-2 antennae. This structure typically features a Galβ1-4GlcNAcβ1-2(Galβ1-4GlcNAcβ1-6)Manα1-R motif, representing a common branching pattern in complex N-glycans.

2′-fucosyllactose is a human milk oligosaccharide composed of lactose with an α1-2-linked fucose attached to the galactose residue. It is known to inhibit pathogen binding by mimicking host cell surface receptors.
A galactose residue that is modified by sulfation at the 3-O position. This modification is recognized as a ligand involved in the clearance of pituitary hormones from the bloodstream.

A glucosamine residue in heparin or heparan sulfate that is N-sulfated, 6-O-sulfated, and further modified by 3-O-sulfation. This specific modification, known as 3-O-sulfated GlcNS6S, is critical for antithrombin–heparin interaction and is also recognized by certain viruses, highlighting its functional significance in biological processes.

A structural variant of chondroitin sulfate glycosaminoglycan characterized by sulfation of the N-acetylgalactosamine residues at the 4-position, which is relevant to glycosaminoglycan-protein interactions.

Glucosamine residues within heparan sulfate chains that are sulfated at the 6-O position. These residues are subject to modification by endosulfatases (SULFs), which can alter their sulfation status and influence the biological properties of the glycan chain.

6-sulfo-sialyl Lewis X (6-sulfo-SLex) is a sialyl Lewis X (LeX) glycan motif that is further modified by sulfation at the 6-position of the N-acetylglucosamine. As a high-affinity L-selectin ligand (often on mucin-type glycoconjugates), it promotes leukocyte rolling and homing at high endothelial venules and can influence cell–cell interactions in inflammation and cancer.)

6′-sulfo-sialyl Lewis X (6′-sulfo-SLex) is a sialyl Lewis X (SLex) glycan motif that is further modified by sulfation at the 6′ position of the galactose residue. It serves as a recognition ligand for selectins and Siglecs, guiding cell to cell interactions in the immune system and shaping inflammatory responses at mucosal surfaces.
Sialic acids that are modified by acetylation at the 9-hydroxyl position. This modification can influence recognition by sialic acid-binding proteins, such as CD22.

ABO blood group antigens are terminal glycan structures found on glycoproteins and glycolipids that define the A, B, and H blood group types. These glycans serve as receptors for certain viruses and are specifically recognized by lectins and antibodies, playing a key role in blood group determination and immune recognition.

A glycan structure that is attached to a membrane through an alkylacylphosphatidylinositol anchor. This glycan may contain components such as nonacetylated glucosamine, mannose, galactofuranose, and 2-aminoethylphosphonate.
Amylopectin is a branched polysaccharide consisting of α-1,4-linked D-glucose units with α-1,6-linked branch points. It is one of the two major components of starch.

Apiogalacturonan is a class of plant cell wall pectic polysaccharides characterized by a galacturonic acid backbone with β-D-apiose (Apif) and apiobiose residues attached to the O-2 position of some backbone residues. These polysaccharides are found in duckweeds and seagrasses.

Arabinoglucuronoxylan (AGX) is a type of plant cell wall hemicellulose found in gymnosperms, characterized by a xylan backbone that is substituted with both methylglucuronic acid (MeGlcpA) and arabinofuranose (Araf) residues.

A family of glycosphingolipids (GSLs) characteristic of invertebrates, especially arthropods, built on a mactosylceramide core (Manβ1-4Glcβ-ceramide) that may contain multiple N-acetylglucosamine residues and is often further modified with galactose, fucose, glucuronic acid, phosphoethanolamine, or phosphorylcholine.

a-series gangliosides are a class of glycosphingolipids characterized by the presence of a single sialic acid residue attached to the inner galactose of the lactosylceramide core. They are biosynthesized through the addition of sialic acid to GM3 and cannot be directly converted to b-series gangliosides by sialyltransferases.

Asialo-GM1, also known as GA1, is a neutral ganglioside of the ganglio-series with the structure Galβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer. It is formed by extending lactosylceramide with GalNAc (β1-4) followed by Gal (β1-3).

Asialo-GM1, also known as GA1, is a neutral ganglioside of the ganglio-series with the structure Galβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer. It is formed by extending lactosylceramide with GalNAc (β1-4) followed by Gal (β1-3).

N-linked glycans with a complex-type structure characterized by two antennae (branches) extending from the core. These glycans are commonly found on glycoproteins and are known for their specific lectin binding properties.

Biantennary N-glycans are N-linked glycans characterized by two antennae (branches) extending from the core pentasaccharide structure. These branches can be further modified by the addition of sugars such as galactose, sialic acid, or fucose.

A complex-type N-glycan structure that contains a bisecting N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) residue attached via β1-4 linkage to the core mannose of N-glycans. This modification is typically introduced by the enzyme MGAT3.
A β1-4-linked N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) residue attached to the core mannose of N-glycans, formed by the action of N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase III (MGAT3).

A structural feature in certain fungal N-glycans where an N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is attached in an α1-4 linkage to the β-mannose core, distinct from the common β1-4-linked bisecting GlcNAc in mammals.

The blood group A determinant is a glycan structure found on the surface of red blood cells that defines blood group A. It is formed by the terminal addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen, a reaction catalyzed by A-transferase. This structure is a key component in distinguishing blood group A from other blood groups.
A class of glycan epitopes found on glycoproteins and glycolipids that determine human blood groups, including the A, B, O(H), and other antigens.

The blood group B determinant is a specific glycan epitope, typically Galα1-3(Fucα1-2)Gal-R, present on the surface of red blood cells, glycoproteins, and glycolipids. It defines the blood group B antigen in humans and is formed by the terminal addition of galactose to the H antigen, catalyzed by B-transferase. This structure is recognized by specific antibodies and lectins, and is a key determinant in blood group typing.

The blood group H determinant is a glycan antigen and epitope characterized by the presence of an α1-2-linked fucose residue, synthesized by α1-2 fucosyltransferase (FucT). It is formed by the addition of α1-2-linked fucose to the terminal galactose of a type 1 unit (Galβ1-3GlcNAc), resulting in the structure Fucα1-2Galβ1-3GlcNAc. This determinant serves as a precursor for ABO blood group antigens.

exact_synonyms: type 1 blood group H core trisaccharide
description: A core trisaccharide glycan structure with the sequence Fucα1-2Galβ1-3GlcNAc, characteristic of the type 1 blood group H antigen. This structure can serve as a core that may be further substituted or capped in various glycan contexts.
An N-linked glycan characterized by a branched structure, which can carry ABO(H) antigens and poly-LacNAc extensions.

b-series gangliosides are a class of glycosphingolipids characterized by the presence of two sialic acid residues attached to the inner galactose. Examples include GD3 and GT1b. These structures are formed through the action of sialyltransferases during glycosphingolipid biosynthesis.

Callose is a plant and fungal polysaccharide composed primarily of β-1,3-linked glucose residues, sometimes featuring β-1,6 branches. It plays important roles in cell wall structure and is involved in defense responses.
Cellobiose is a disaccharide composed of two β-1,4-linked glucose residues and serves as the repeating unit of cellulose.

Cellulose is a linear polysaccharide made up of β-1,4-linked glucose units. It serves as the primary structural component of plant cell walls and is one of the most abundant biopolymers found in nature.

Chitin is a linear polymer composed of β-D-N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) residues linked via β(1→4) glycosidic bonds. It forms the structural backbone of invertebrate exoskeletons and fungal cell walls, providing strength and rigidity.

Chitobiose is a disaccharide composed of two β(1→4)-linked N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) units, forming the core structure of N-glycans. In some biological contexts, this chitobiose core can be elongated by additional monosaccharides, particularly in cases involving defects in mannosyltransferase activity or in certain parasitic organisms, resulting in extended chitobiose motifs.

Chondroitin is a glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetylgalactosamine and glucuronic acid. These units can be further modified by sulfation and epimerization. Chondroitin serves as the backbone for chondroitin sulfate and related structures.

Chondroitin sulfate A is a subtype of chondroitin sulfate glycosaminoglycan characterized by repeating disaccharide units containing glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine, with sulfation typically occurring at the 4-position of the N-acetylgalactosamine residue.

Chondroitin sulfate B, also known as dermatan sulfate, is a glycosaminoglycan characterized by the presence of iduronic acid–containing disaccharide units. It is formed by the epimerization of glucuronic acid in chondroitin sulfate chains.

Chondroitin sulfate C is a subtype of chondroitin sulfate glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units containing glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine, with sulfation typically occurring at the 6-position of the N-acetylgalactosamine residue.

Chondroitin sulfate is a sulfated glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetylgalactosamine and glucuronic acid, with variable sulfation patterns. It commonly occurs as chains covalently attached to proteoglycans and can be found as oligosaccharide segments (typically 4–20 residues) derived from or mimicking portions of the full polysaccharide.

A glycan modification in which a mannose residue is attached through a carbon-carbon (C-glycosidic) bond, most commonly found on tryptophan residues within thrombospondin type 1 repeats (TSRs) and certain complement proteins.

Complex gangliosides are gangliosides with multiple glycan extensions beyond the simple monosialylated core, often containing additional sialic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine residues. They are synthesized by the sequential action of sialyltransferases and N-acetylgalactosaminyltransferases.

Complex glycans are oligosaccharides with branched and extended structures, typically referring to mature N-glycans or O-glycans that have undergone extensive processing and addition of various sugars beyond the core. These structures often feature complex sugar chains, such as sialylated, sulfated, glucuronylated, or zwitterionic modifications, and include both complex N-glycans and other complex-type glycans.

Complex glycolipids are glycolipids that possess oligosaccharide chains longer or more branched than those found in simple mono- or disaccharide glycolipids. They are synthesized from precursors like glucosylceramide through additional glycosylation steps.

Complex O-glycans are O-glycans with extended and branched structures, typically formed by the sequential addition of monosaccharides to an initial N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) linked to serine or threonine residues of proteins. These glycans are highly diverse and are commonly found on mucins and other glycoproteins.

Complex-type N-glycans are a class of N-linked glycans characterized by the addition of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) to the core mannose residues, followed by further branching and elongation with sugars such as galactose, sialic acid, and fucose. These glycans are typically multiantennary and highly branched, formed after mannose trimming in the Golgi apparatus and subsequent action of glycosyltransferases. Their biosynthesis involves full processing of the GlcNAcMan5GlcNAc2 intermediate, and they are commonly found on glycoproteins in higher eukaryotes.

Complex-type N-glycans that are modified by the addition of sialic acid residues at the terminal positions of their branches. These sialylated structures contribute to a negative charge, play roles in biological recognition, and are often used to enhance the circulatory half-life and alter the biodistribution of glycoproteins.

The core 1 O-glycan, also known as Galβ1-3GalNAcα1-O-Ser/Thr, is a disaccharide structure that forms the basic core of mucin-type O-glycans in vertebrates and some invertebrates. It consists of a galactose β1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine α-linked to serine or threonine residues on proteins. This structure is the most common O-GalNAc glycan, generated by the enzyme C1GALT1 (T-synthase), and serves as a precursor for further elongation and modification, including sialylation and sulfation, in O-glycosylation.

Core 2 O-glycan is a mucin-type O-GalNAc glycan structure formed by the addition of a GlcNAcβ1-6 branch to the GalNAc residue of core 1, resulting in the structure Galβ1-3(GlcNAcβ1-6)GalNAcα1-O-Ser/Thr. This structure is a major branch of O-GalNAc glycans, is more cell type–specific than core 1, and serves as a scaffold for further extension and modification, including the formation of selectin ligands.
A mucin-type O-glycan structure characterized by the addition of GlcNAcβ1-3 to GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr, resulting in the structure GlcNAcβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr.

Core 4 O-GalNAc glycan is a mucin-type O-glycan structure where the core 3 structure (GlcNAcβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr) is further branched by the addition of a GlcNAc residue via a β1-6 linkage, resulting in the structure GlcNAcβ1-6(GlcNAcβ1-3)GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr.
A fucose residue attached in α1-6 linkage to the innermost GlcNAc of N-glycans, serving as a key structural feature that influences glycan function.

Core M1 O-mannose glycan is one of the three main core structures (M1–M3) of O-mannose glycans, characterized by the addition of a single N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) in β1-2 linkage to a protein-linked mannose. This core structure is generated by the action of POMGNT1 and can be further extended by various glycosyltransferases, representing a specific and conserved oligosaccharide core in O-mannosylation.

Core M2 O-mannose glycan is a type of O-mannose glycan core structure characterized by the addition of two N-acetylglucosamines (GlcNAc) to a protein-linked mannose via β1-2 and β1-6 linkages. This structure is formed from core M1 through the action of MGAT5B and can be further extended by various glycosyltransferases.

The core M3 O-mannose glycan is one of the three main core structures (M1–M3) of O-mannose glycans, representing a specific conserved oligosaccharide core found on mammalian α-dystroglycan. It serves as a priming substrate for the addition of repeating disaccharide units (Xyl-α3-GlcA-β3-)n, a process catalyzed by the LARGE1 or LARGE2 glycosyltransferases.
A class of gangliosides characterized by the presence of three sialic acid residues attached to the glycan core, including structures such as GT3 and its derivatives.
Cyclic β1-2 glucans are polysaccharides consisting of 17–25 glucose units connected by β1-2 linkages. They are synthesized by certain bacteria, such as Agrobacterium.

Dermatan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) consisting of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetylgalactosamine and iduronic acid, which is formed by epimerization of glucuronic acid. The chain is modified by O-sulfation and is typically found as a sulfated polysaccharide component of proteoglycans.
Dextran is a class of polysaccharides composed primarily of α(1→6)-linked D-glucose units with occasional α(1→3) branches, and is commonly produced by certain bacteria.
Di-N-acetylbacillosamine (diNAcBac) is a bacterial monosaccharide containing two N-acetyl groups, and is commonly found at the reducing end of certain bacterial N-linked oligosaccharides.
A glycan motif composed of the Lewis a antigen with two sialic acid residues attached. It is present on colonic epithelial cells and its expression is altered in colon cancer.

An extended core-1 O-glycan is a core-1 O-glycan (Galβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr) that is further elongated by the addition of extra monosaccharides, such as in the biosynthesis of sulfated selectin ligands.

Fructans are storage polysaccharides made primarily of fructose units. They are commonly found in green plants, where they are stored in vacuoles and serve as energy reserves. Fructans may also contribute to plant protection against abiotic stress.

Fucoidans are sulfated polysaccharides mainly composed of fucose residues, typically featuring alternating 1-3 and 1-4 linkages. They are isolated from brown algae and are recognized for their diverse biological activities.

Fucosylated glycans are glycans that contain fucose residues, typically attached through α1-2, α1-3, or α1-4 linkages. These structures play important roles in biological processes such as host-pathogen interactions and cell signaling.
N-glycans that are modified by the addition of fucose residues. The presence of fucose can influence various biological processes, including neural development and function.

A disaccharide composed of fucose linked α1-2 to galactose. This motif is commonly found as a terminal structure on host epithelial glycoconjugates, with its expression regulated by bacterial exposure and fucosyltransferase activity.

A complex-type N-glycan that lacks galactose residues on its antennae (agalactosylated), typically featuring a core Man3GlcNAc2 structure with two terminal GlcNAc residues. This structure is commonly found on glycoproteins and is recognized by mannose-binding proteins.

Galabiose is a disaccharide composed of two galactose residues linked by an alpha1-4 glycosidic bond (Galα1-4Gal). It serves as a recognition motif for certain bacterial toxins and adhesins, and is found in glycolipids and glycoproteins, including as part of glycosphingolipids where it can be linked to ceramide. Galabiose-containing structures are present in the large intestine epithelium and function as receptors for specific pathogens.
A polysaccharide composed primarily of galactose residues, commonly found in fungal and plant cell walls.

Galactolipids are a class of glycolipids characterized by one or more galactose residues attached to a lipid moiety. They are commonly found in plant membranes and play important roles in membrane structure and function.
A polysaccharide composed of a mannose backbone with galactose side chains, commonly found in plant and fungal cell walls.
A branch of an N-glycan that ends with a galactose residue, typically in a β1-4 linkage to N-acetylglucosamine.

Galactosylceramide is a glycosphingolipid composed of a ceramide backbone with a single galactose residue β-linked to it. It is predominantly found in the nervous system, especially in brain and myelin lipids of deuterostome animals.
A disaccharide composed of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) α1-3 linked to galactose. This structure is found in blood group A antigens and certain glycolipids.

This is a trisaccharide fragment found in the Campylobacter jejuni N-glycan heptasaccharide, composed of GalNAcα1-4GalNAcα1-3-diNAcBac, where diNAcBac refers to 2,4-diacetamido-2,4,6-trideoxyglucopyranose.
A disaccharide composed of two N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues linked via an α1-4 glycosidic bond; it is a component of the Campylobacter jejuni N-glycan heptasaccharide.
A disaccharide composed of galactose alpha1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine, commonly found as a terminal structure in mucin-type O-glycans.
A disaccharide composed of two galactose residues connected by an alpha1-3 glycosidic bond. This structure is found as a capping motif on certain core trisaccharides in glycan structures.

A trisaccharide composed of galactose alpha1-3 linked to galactose beta1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine. This structure is a common terminal motif in many mammalian glycans but is notably absent in Old World primates.
A disaccharide composed of galactose linked alpha1-3 to glucose (alpha anomer). It can be found as a capping structure on certain core trisaccharides.
A trisaccharide motif composed of galactose β1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine, which is β1-4 linked to galactose. This structure is found as a component of gangliosides GM1b and GA1.

This tetrasaccharide motif consists of galactose β1-3 linked to N-acetylglucosamine, which is β1-3 linked to galactose, itself β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine. It is recognized by TRA-1-60 and TRA-1-81 antibodies as part of keratan sulfate–related antigens.

Ganglio-series glycosphingolipids are a class of glycosphingolipids defined by a specific core oligosaccharide structure (Galβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer), which can be further extended and sialylated to form gangliosides. These molecules are predominant in the mammalian brain and are classified based on the number of sialic acid residues and their migration order on thin-layer chromatography, such as GM (mono), GD (di), and GT (tri) series.

Gangliosides are glycosphingolipids (glycolipids) characterized by one or more sialic acid residues linked to an oligosaccharide chain, which is attached to a ceramide lipid. As a subclass of sialylated glycosphingolipids, they are abundant in the nervous system, particularly the brain, and function as important cell surface molecules involved in cell signaling, recognition, and as receptors for toxins and viruses.
Gb3, also known as the Pk antigen, is a type of glycosphingolipid containing a trisaccharide core structure with the sequence Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glc. It acts as a receptor for Shiga toxins.
The Pk antigen is a type of glycosphingolipid containing a trisaccharide core structure with the sequence Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glc. It acts as a receptor for Shiga toxins.

CD77 is a neutral glycosphingolipid consisting of Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer, also known as globotriaosylceramide (Gb3). It serves as a tumor-associated carbohydrate antigen, being highly enriched in certain cancers such as Burkitt’s lymphoma, and is recognized by specific monoclonal antibodies. As a component of lipid raft microdomains, CD77 influences cell signaling and can modulate tumor cell growth and invasion.
Gb4, also known as globoside, is a type of glycosphingolipid containing a tetrasaccharide core structure with the sequence GalNAcβ1-3Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glc, found in the P antigen (Gb4) glycosphingolipid.

A glycosphingolipid antigen with the structure GalNAcβ1-3Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer, belonging to the globoseries. It is the defining determinant of the P blood group system, carried on glycolipids of red blood cells and other tissues. Along with related glycans such as Gb3 (Pk antigen), P antigen can act as a receptor for microbial toxins and lectins, and has been implicated in cancer cell recognition and signaling.
GD1a is a ganglioside, specifically a glycosphingolipid containing two sialic acid residues. It is commonly found in brain tissue and is a member of the GD1 ganglioside family.
GD1b is a ganglioside, specifically a glycosphingolipid containing two sialic acid residues. It is predominantly found in neural tissues and is a member of the GD1 ganglioside family.

GD1 refers to a class of acidic glycosphingolipids known as gangliosides that contain two sialic acid residues. These molecules are commonly found in neural tissues, and the GD1 group includes specific members such as GD1a and GD1b.

Gg4 (gangliotetraosylceramide) is a glycosphingolipid, specifically a ganglioside, consisting of a ceramide backbone attached to a tetrasaccharide chain. It belongs to the globo-series of glycolipids.

Glc3Man9GlcNAc2 is a fully assembled N-glycan precursor oligosaccharide consisting of three glucose, nine mannose, and two N-acetylglucosamine residues. It is transferred en bloc to nascent proteins, covalently linked to asparagine, during N-glycosylation in eukaryotes, representing the initial glycan attached to glycoproteins before further processing in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus.
A repeating disaccharide unit composed of glucuronic acid and N-acetylglucosamine, characteristic of the NAc-domains in glycosaminoglycans such as heparan sulfate.
A repeating disaccharide unit composed of glucuronic acid β1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine, which forms the backbone structure of chondroitin sulfate glycosaminoglycans.
A disaccharide epitope composed of glucuronic acid β1-3 linked to galactose, typically with a reducing end aglycone (R). It is recognized as the unsulfated HNK epitope.
A glycan motif in which N-acetylglucosamine phosphate is linked to mannose through a phosphodiester bond. This structure is recognized by the cation-independent mannose 6-phosphate receptor.
A disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-2 linked to mannose, which is α1-3 linked to another sugar. This structure is commonly found in branched N-glycan structures.
A disaccharide motif in which N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is β1-2 linked to mannose, which is α1-6 linked to another sugar. This structure is commonly found as part of branched N-glycan structures.
A disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-4 linked to galactose. This structure is commonly found in both N-glycans and O-glycans.
A disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-4 linked to another GlcNAc. This structure is a common core component in N-glycans.
A glycosphingolipid structure in which N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is β1-4 linked to glucose, and the glucose is attached to a ceramide moiety. This structure is found in certain invertebrates.

A core disaccharide structure found in complex-type N-glycans, consisting of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-4 linked to mannose (Man). This motif is produced by the enzyme MGAT3 and is recognized by the E-PHA lectin.
A repeating disaccharide unit of glucose (Glc) α1-4 linked to glucose, forming the linear backbone of glycogen and other α-glucans.

A glycosidic linkage in which glucose (Glc) is α1-linked to mannose (Man) through a phosphate group. This structure is associated with the activities of glucose phosphotransferase and Glc-1-phosphate phosphodiesterase.

A disaccharide modification found on O-fucosylated serine or threonine residues, where a glucose (Glc) is β1-3 linked to a fucose (Fuc) that is α-linked to serine or threonine. This structure is commonly present on thrombospondin type 1 repeats (TSRs).

Globo-series glycosphingolipids are a class of glycosphingolipids characterized by terminal α-galactose residues. They are the most abundant glycolipids in erythrocytes and are degraded by the enzyme α-galactosidase.

Glucans are polysaccharides composed of glucose monomers linked by glycosidic bonds. They include various linkage types (such as β1-3, β1-4, β1-6, α1-3, and α1-4) and form the structural basis of cellulose and other fungal and plant cell wall components.
A hemicellulosic polysaccharide composed of glucose and mannose residues, commonly found in fungal cell walls and plant tissues.
Glucosylceramide (Glc-Cer) is a glycosphingolipid composed of a ceramide backbone with a single glucose residue attached through a β-glycosidic linkage.

Glucuronoarabinoxylan is a hemicellulosic polysaccharide present in plant cell walls, particularly in grasses. It features a xylan backbone that is substituted with glucuronic acid and arabinose residues.

Glucuronoxylan is a hemicellulosic polysaccharide characterized by a xylan backbone substituted with α-D-glucuronic acid or methylated glucuronic acid at the O-2 position. It is a major component of secondary cell walls in woody and herbaceous eudicots as well as higher plants.

Glycogen is a highly branched glucose polymer composed mainly of α(1-4)-linked glucose residues with α(1-6)-linked branch points. It serves as a major glucose storage polysaccharide in animals, allowing for rapid mobilization of glucose when needed.

Glycoglycerolipids are a class of glycolipids characterized by glycan moieties attached to the C-3 hydroxyl group of diacylglycerol or alkyl(acyl)glycerol, distinguishing them from glycosphingolipids.

Glycoinositolphospholipids (GIPLs) are a class of glycolipids structurally related to glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, but are distinguished by extensive substitution with galactose, N-acetylglucosamine, and sialic acid residues.

Glycolipids are glycoconjugates composed of a glycan moiety attached to a lipid. They include major classes such as brain glycolipids, which are abundant in neural tissue, as well as shorter chain variants.

Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are linear polysaccharides composed of repeating acidic disaccharide units, typically containing a hexosamine and a hexose or hexuronic acid. These chains are often sulfated and are covalently attached to core proteins to form proteoglycans. GAGs, which include heparan sulfate, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, and others, are critical for protein interactions and the structure of the extracellular matrix in eukaryotes.

Glycosphingolipids (GSLs) are a subclass of glycolipids composed of a glycan (oligosaccharide) linked to a ceramide lipid moiety. They are major components of animal cell membranes, synthesized by the stepwise addition of sugars to ceramide, and are classified based on their glycan structures. GSLs play important roles in membrane structure, cell–cell recognition, and signal transduction. They are degraded in lysosomes, and defects in their catabolism can result in pathological accumulation.

Glycosylceramides are glycolipids consisting of a ceramide backbone linked to a short glycan chain, such as glucosylceramide (Glc-Cer) and galactosylceramide (Gal-Cer). These molecules are commonly found in fungi and play important roles in membrane structure and function.
A type of glycolipid composed of one or more monosaccharides attached to a diacylglycerol backbone, frequently featuring α1-6-linked galactopyranose residues.

Glycosylinositolphosphorylceramides (GIPCs) are plant- and fungi-specific glycolipids composed of a ceramide backbone linked to a glycosylated inositol phosphate headgroup. They are major components of the plant plasma membrane and are absent in animals.

GM1b is a ganglioside with the structure Neu5Acα2-3Galβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer. It is biosynthesized by the α2-3 sialylation of GA1. It participates in membrane organization and cell–cell recognition.

GM1 is a ganglioside, a type of glycosphingolipid containing one sialic acid residue. It consists of a ceramide lipid linked to a pentasaccharide glycan headgroup, which is recognized by proteins such as cholera toxin. GM1 is formed by the addition of galactose to GM2 and plays important roles as a receptor for cholera toxin and in cell signaling.

GM2 is a ganglioside, a type of glycosphingolipid containing one sialic acid residue, and is found in the brain. It serves as a biosynthetic precursor to GM1 and is characterized by a sialylated glycan structure. GM2 accumulates in certain lysosomal storage diseases such as Sandhoff disease, and its degradation requires the GM2-activator protein.

GM3, also known as Ganglioside GM3, is the simplest member of the ganglioside series. It consists of a ceramide linked to a sialylated lactose, containing a single sialic acid residue. GM3 serves as a precursor for more complex gangliosides and is involved in modulating insulin receptor responsiveness.

GPI glycans are the glycan (oligosaccharide) portion of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, which are glycolipid structures that tether proteins to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane. The core GPI glycan consists of a conserved sequence, typically including mannose and glucosamine residues linked to myo-inositol phospholipid, and serves as a scaffold for further modifications and protein attachment. GPI glycans can vary between species and tissues, contributing to the diversity of GPI-anchored proteins, and may include additional side chains. In some organisms, the lipid component is inositolphosphoceramide. The GPI glycan is preassembled before protein attachment and is essential for the function of GPI anchors.
GQ1b is a ganglioside, a type of glycosphingolipid that contains sialic acid. It is found in cell membranes and is recognized as an antigen in certain autoimmune responses.
GT1b is a ganglioside, which is a type of glycosphingolipid containing sialic acid. It functions as a docking site for specific proteins and toxins on neuronal cells.
GT1c is a ganglioside, a complex glycosphingolipid formed by the galactosylation of GT2 and characterized by the presence of multiple sialic acid residues.

Hemicellulose refers to a class of branched plant cell wall polysaccharides characterized by a backbone of 1-4-linked β-D-pyranosyl residues, such as glucose, mannose, or xylose. This group includes xylans, glucuronoxylans, galactomannans, and xyloglucans. Hemicelluloses are synthesized in the Golgi apparatus and secreted into the apoplast, where they contribute to the structure and function of plant cell walls.
The heparan sulfate backbone consists of a repeating disaccharide unit made up of glucuronic acid (GlcA) β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) α1-4.

Heparan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units of glucuronic acid (GlcA) and N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc), assembled as a copolymer and extensively modified by sulfation and epimerization. It is synthesized on a linkage tetrasaccharide attached to serine residues of core proteins, forming chains that are found on proteoglycans. Heparan sulfate oligosaccharides are short segments derived from or mimicking these chains. Heparan sulfate plays important roles in cell signaling and molecular interactions.

Heparin is a highly sulfated glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units, typically containing N-sulfated glucosamine and iduronic acid, both variably sulfated. Structurally related to heparan sulfate, heparin chains are often attached to core proteins and are well known for their anticoagulant activity and high affinity for various proteins.

Heteroxylan refers to a class of hemicellulosic polysaccharides found in the secondary cell walls of seed-producing plants. These polysaccharides are characterized by a β-1,4-linked D-xylopyranose backbone with various substituents, and are classified based on the type and abundance of these substituents.
A class of N-linked glycans characterized by multiple antennae (branches) that contain complex sugars. These highly branched structures are less likely to bind to ConA-agarose.

High-mannose N-glycans, also known as oligomannose-type glycans, are a class of N-linked glycans characterized by a core pentasaccharide (Man3GlcNAc2) that is extended exclusively with additional mannose residues, typically resulting in structures with five to nine mannose units. These glycans are biosynthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum from dolichol-linked precursors and are found on glycoproteins, where they play important roles in protein folding, quality control, trafficking, and recognition. High-mannose N-glycans can serve as ligands for lectins, are substrates for enzymes such as endo H, and may be further modified, for example by phosphorylation during lysosomal targeting. They lack complex antennae and are notable for their strong binding to ConA-agarose.

HNK-1 is a carbohydrate epitope, specifically 3-sulfoglucuronyl-galactose, found on various glycans, including those present on glycosphingolipids. Glycosphingolipids that display the HNK-1 epitope have this distinctive glycan structure on their glycan moiety.

Homogalacturonan is a linear homopolysaccharide consisting of 1,4-linked α-D-galacturonic acid residues. It forms a major structural domain of pectin in plant cell walls, contributing to their integrity and function.

Hyaluronan is a high-molecular-weight, linear, nonsulfated glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units of glucuronic acid (GlcA) β1-3 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-4. These long, polyanionic chains occupy large hydrodynamic volumes and play important roles in cell adhesion, signaling, and tissue structure. Short hyaluronan chains or oligosaccharides, generated by enzymatic cleavage, can interact with membrane proteins such as CD44 and TLR2/4, modulating signaling pathways and inducing biological effects including apoptosis in cancer cells.

Hybrid N-glycans are a class of N-linked glycans that display features of both oligomannose and complex N-glycans. They are characterized by having one branch (antenna) that retains mannose residues, while the other branch is extended with N-acetylglucosamine and other complex sugars. These structures are biosynthesized when the GlcNAcMan5GlcNAc2 intermediate produced by MGAT1 is not fully processed by α-mannosidase II, resulting in glycans that are intermediates between oligomannose and complex N-glycans. Hybrid N-glycans can be further modified in the Golgi apparatus.

A branched poly-N-acetyllactosamine glycan determinant formed by β1-6 branching of repeating Galβ1-4GlcNAc units, distinguishing it from the linear i antigen. It is carried on N- and O-glycans and glycolipids, serves as part of the I blood group system, and its expression changes during development (i → I conversion) and in certain diseases.

The i antigen consists of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetyllactosamine (Galβ1-4GlcNAcβ1-3/6) arranged in a linear fashion. These linear poly-N-acetyllactosamine chains can act as precursors for further branching and are involved in the biosynthesis of antigens such as the I antigen.

Glycan antigens structurally related to keratan sulfate, including motifs such as the tetrasaccharide Galβ1-3GlcNAcβ1-3Galβ1-4GlcNAc, which are recognized by specific monoclonal antibodies such as TRA-1-60 and TRA-1-81.

Keratan sulfate (KS) is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) composed of repeating disaccharide units of galactose and N-acetylglucosamine, which are variably sulfated. These sulfated poly-N-acetyllactosamine chains are typically attached to core proteins at asparagine or serine/threonine residues, forming proteoglycans such as decorin, biglycan, versican, and lumican in various tissues.

LacdiNAc (N-acetylgalactosamine β1-4 N-acetylglucosamine, GalNAcβ1-4GlcNAc) is a disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc). It is commonly found as an outer structure in some invertebrate glycans and as a motif in N-glycans, with its presence determined by specific glycosyltransferases in lineage-specific glycosylation pathways. LacdiNAc is a glycan motif found in various taxa.

LacNAc (N-acetyllactosamine, Galβ1-4GlcNAc) is a disaccharide motif commonly found in vertebrate N- and O-glycans, serving as a building block for more complex glycan structures such as Lewis antigens.

Lacto-series glycosphingolipids are a class of glycosphingolipids defined by a core structure containing N-acetyllactosamine (LacNAc) repeats. These glycolipids are especially prominent in secretory organs and play important roles in cellular recognition and membrane structure.

Lactosylceramide (LacCer) is a glycosphingolipid core structure composed of a galactose residue β1-4 linked to glucose, which is further attached to a ceramide moiety. It serves as the most common core structure of vertebrate glycosphingolipids.

A repeating disaccharide-phosphate unit composed of galactose (β1-4 linked to mannose) with a phosphate group, forming the backbone of the phosphoglycan polymer in Leishmania lipophosphoglycan (LPG) and related phosphoglycosylated protein glycans. This structural motif is characteristic of the phosphoglycan portions of LPG and proteophosphoglycan (PPG) in certain protozoa.
A fructan polysaccharide composed of linear β2-6-linked D-fructofuranose units, commonly found in grasses.

Lewis antigens are a family of fucosylated glycan epitopes, including Lewis a, b, x, and y, that function as blood group antigens and mediate cell-cell interactions. These structures are characterized by the addition of L-fucosyl residues to a glycan backbone, resulting in branched motifs commonly found on glycoproteins and glycolipids.
Lewis a is a fucosylated type 1 chain glycan epitope with the structure Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAc, commonly referred to as the Lewis a antigen.
Lewis b is a fucosylated type 1 chain glycan epitope, with the structure Fucα1-2Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAc, and is known as the Lewis b antigen.

Lewis x (Lex) is a fucosylated type 2 chain glycan epitope with the structure Galβ1-4(Fucα1-3)GlcNAc. It is found on N-glycans, O-glycans, and glycolipids in animals and some plants. Glycans containing the Lewis x motif are characterized by the addition of this fucosylated N-acetyllactosamine structure to the glycan chain.

The lipid A-core is a glycan-lipid structure in which lipid A is covalently linked to the core oligosaccharide region of lipopolysaccharide (LPS). This structure serves as a substrate for transport and further modification in Gram-negative bacteria.

Lipo-chitooligosaccharides (LCOs) are a class of glycolipids consisting of a chitin-derived oligosaccharide backbone linked to a fatty acid. They are produced by bacterial and fungal symbionts and are recognized by plant receptors, triggering various biological responses.

Lipoglycans are a broad class of glycoconjugates in which a glycan, such as an oligosaccharide or polysaccharide, is covalently linked to a lipid moiety. These molecules contribute to cell membrane structure and function.
A complex glycoconjugate composed of lipid, peptide, and phosphoglycan components, as exemplified by the lipopeptidophosphoglycan (LPPG) found in Entamoeba histolytica.

Lipophosphoglycan (LPPG) is a major surface glycoconjugate of Leishmania parasites, consisting of a phosphoglycan chain linked to a lipid anchor. It functions as a virulence factor and plays a key role in parasite biology.

Lipopolysaccharide is a major glycolipid component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, composed of lipid A, a core oligosaccharide, and an O-antigen polysaccharide. It acts as a potent antigen and pathogen-associated molecular pattern (PAMP).

Lipoteichoic acids (LTAs) are anionic glycopolymers present in the cell envelopes of Gram-positive bacteria. They typically consist of polyglycerol phosphate chains anchored to a glycolipid, and display diverse carbohydrate structures. Their biosynthetic pathways are distinct from those of wall teichoic acids.

M7BC is a specific isomer of the Man7 (M7) high-mannose N-glycan. It is characterized by the absence of residues i and k compared to M8B, resulting in the exposure of an α1–6-linked mannose (residue j). M7BC is generated from M8B through the enzymatic action of EDEM1 and EDEM3.
M8B is a specific isomer of the Man8 (M8) high-mannose N-glycan. It is generated from Man9 (M9) through demannosylation, a process mainly catalyzed by the enzyme EDEM2 in the endoplasmic reticulum.
A core N-glycan structure composed of three mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues, representing the minimal N-glycan core found in eukaryotes.
An N-glycan core structure consisting of five mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues, commonly found on glycoproteins and not associated with targeting them for degradation.
An N-glycan core structure composed of six mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues, commonly found as an intermediate in the biosynthesis of N-linked glycans.

N-glycans that contain mannose-6-phosphate (Man-6-P) residues. These glycans were first identified on lysosomal enzymes and are essential for proper lysosomal trafficking, serving as recognition markers for targeting enzymes to lysosomes.
Man7GlcNAc2 is an N-glycan core structure composed of seven mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues. It represents a high-mannose intermediate in the biosynthesis of N-glycans.
Man8GlcNAc2 is an N-glycan core structure composed of eight mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues. It represents a high-mannose intermediate in the biosynthesis of N-glycans.
Man9GlcNAc2 is an N-glycan core structure composed of nine mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues. It represents a high-mannose intermediate in the biosynthesis of N-glycans.

Mannans are polysaccharides composed mainly of mannose residues, typically linked by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds. They are found in plant cell walls, as well as in the cell walls of fungi, yeast, and some bacteria, where they can serve structural or signaling functions.

A type of N-linked glycan characterized by mannose residues at its non-reducing ends. These glycans play a role in targeting proteins to specific cells, such as macrophages, by serving as recognition signals.

Mannosylated lipoarabinomannan (ManLAM) is a form of lipoarabinomannan (LAM) found in mycobacteria, characterized by mannose residues capping its structure. As a glycolipid, ManLAM plays a key role in modulating immune responses by interacting with C-type lectin receptors.

This is a glycosylphosphoceramide structure identified in Aspergillus fumigatus, featuring a galactomannan chain with a defined mannosylated core (Manα1-2Manα1-2Manα1-6Manα1-4GlcN) that is directly linked to inositolphosphoceramide, notably lacking a bridging phosphoethanolamine.

A disaccharide consisting of two mannose residues connected by an α1-3 glycosidic bond. This structure can function as an inhibitor of mannose-binding proteins that are involved in adhesion processes.
A glycosphingolipid core structure found in certain invertebrates, consisting of a β1-4 linked mannose and glucose attached to a ceramide lipid.

Matriglycan is a specialized repeating disaccharide glycan synthesized on α-dystroglycan. It serves as a binding site for extracellular matrix proteins and certain viral proteins, and is an extended O-mannosyl glycan essential for the connection between muscle and the extracellular matrix.

Methanochondroitin is a rigid fibrillar polysaccharide similar to chondroitin, composed of repeating units of one uronic acid and two N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues, and is found as a cell surface polymer.

A monoantennary N-glycan is an N-glycan structure characterized by having a single antenna (branch) extending from the core. This type of glycan is often produced in engineered CHO cells, is typically unsialylated, and features exposed galactose acceptor sites.

A high-mannose-type N-glycan containing a single glucose residue. This structure is recognized by calnexin and calreticulin in the endoplasmic reticulum and plays a key role in the glycoprotein folding quality control system.

A ganglioside that contains a single sialic acid residue, such as GM3. These structures typically terminate in Neu5Acα2-3Gal and can be recognized by certain lectins, including those involved in HIV interactions.

Mucin-type O-glycans (O-GalNAc glycans) are a class of O-linked glycans that begin with the attachment of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to serine or threonine residues on proteins. They are commonly found on mucins and other glycoproteins, sharing a core GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr structure that can be further extended or modified by additional sugars.

Multiantennary complex-type N-glycans are N-glycans with a complex-type core structure that feature multiple antennae (branches) extending from the core mannose residues. These structures are characteristic of animal glycoproteins.
N-acetyllactosamine (LN) is a disaccharide motif with the structure Galβ1-4GlcNAc, commonly found on glycans. It serves as an acceptor for fucosylation by human fucosyltransferases III–VII.

Neolacto-series glycosphingolipids are a class of glycosphingolipids (GSLs) defined by a neutral core sequence. They are commonly found on certain hematopoietic cells, including leukocytes, in mammals.

Neu5Acα2-3Gal is a disaccharide motif where N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac) is linked in an alpha 2-3 configuration to galactose (Gal). This structure is commonly found as a terminal motif on glycans and is recognized by certain viruses and lectins.

Neu5Acα2-6Gal is a disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac) linked in an alpha 2-6 configuration to galactose (Gal). This structure is commonly found as a terminal motif on human airway epithelial cell glycans and serves as a receptor determinant for certain viruses.

This trisaccharide consists of N-glycolylneuraminic acid (Neu5Gc) linked α2-3 to galactose (Gal), which is β1-4 linked to glucose (Glc). It is found in certain glycolipids and is recognized by specific bacterial strains.

The N-glycan core is the conserved core structure (Manα1–6(Manα1–3)Manβ1–4GlcNAcβ1–4GlcNAcβ1–Asn) found in all N-linked glycans found on eukaryotic proteins. It is assembled during the process of N-glycosylation and is essential for the proper formation and function of glycoproteins.
A type of N-glycan that carries corneal-type keratan sulfate (KS, type I) chains and is degraded by enzymes involved in N-glycan catabolism.

N-glycans are a class of glycans covalently attached to the asparagine residues of proteins via N-glycosidic bonds. They are characterized by a conserved core pentasaccharide structure and are commonly found in animals, but the N-glycosylation system is present across all domains of life. N-glycans are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, and their structures can be further elaborated with various monosaccharides such as GlcNAc, GalNAc, Gal, Man, Fuc, and sialic acid. These glycans play important roles in protein folding, stability, and cell signaling.

Sialic acids that are modified by the addition of an O-acetyl group at one or more hydroxyl positions. These modifications can influence recognition by viral and immune receptors and are regulated by specific esterases.

The O-antigen is a repetitive glycan polymer that constitutes the outermost domain of the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in Gram-negative bacteria. It is highly variable in structure and serves as a major determinant of antigenic diversity among bacterial strains.

O-fucose glycans are glycans in which fucose is O-linked to serine or threonine residues, most notably found on Notch receptors. These structures play important roles in regulating signaling pathways that are critical for cell differentiation and development.

O-GalNAc core structures are conserved oligosaccharide cores formed by the extension of the initial O-linked GalNAc residue on serine or threonine. These structures, known as cores 1–4, serve as the foundational building blocks for complex O-GalNAc glycans, particularly in mucins, and are essential for O-glycan biosynthesis in vertebrates.

O-GalNAc glycans are a class of O-linked glycans initiated by the attachment of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to serine or threonine residues on proteins. They are commonly found in mucins and other glycoproteins, and can be extended to form diverse structures, including blood group and Lewis antigens.

O-GalNAc-linked sialoglycans are a type of O-GalNAc glycan that have been further modified by the addition of sialic acid residues. These structures are commonly found on mucins and other glycoproteins, where the sialic acid imparts extended and negatively charged properties to the glycan chains.

O-Glc glycans are glycans composed of a single glucose residue that is O-linked to serine or threonine residues of proteins. This type of O-glycosylation is found in various glycoconjugates and represents a simple form of protein glycosylation.

O-glycans are a class of glycans covalently attached to the serine or threonine residues of proteins via O-glycosidic bonds. Common in animals, they display diverse core structures often containing GalNAc, GlcNAc, Gal, fucose, and sialic acid. O-glycans are synthesized in the Golgi apparatus and play important roles in protein function, stability, and cell-cell interactions.

Oligogalacturonides are oligosaccharides consisting of linear chains of galacturonic acid residues, usually generated by the partial degradation of pectin. They play important roles in plant growth, development, and defense signaling.

Oligoglucosides are oligosaccharides composed of glucose residues, often featuring 1-6 or 1-3 β-glucose linkages. They can be released from cell walls and may function as signaling molecules, such as oligosaccharins, in plant-pathogen interactions.

Oligomannose refers to glycan structures containing multiple mannose residues, commonly found as part of N-glycans or other glycan classes. These structures are recognized by specific lectins and are involved in protein interactions.

O-linked fucose refers to a glycan modification in which a fucose residue is attached via an O-linkage to serine or threonine residues of proteins. This modification is particularly important in modulating developmental signaling pathways, such as those involving the Notch receptor.
A disaccharide composed of glucose and galactose that is O-linked to hydroxylysine residues, playing an important role in collagen fibril formation.
Glucose residues attached via O-linkage to serine or threonine residues of proteins, which can be further extended by xylose in certain organisms.
Keratan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan that can be O-linked to proteins, especially in skeletal tissues (type II).

A glycan modification in which a mannose residue is attached via an O-linkage to serine or threonine residues of proteins. This modification is conserved across species and is implicated in muscular dystrophies.

O-GlcNAc refers to a single N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) residue attached via an O-linkage, typically a β-linkage, to serine or threonine residues of nuclear, cytoplasmic, and mitochondrial proteins. This modification is a dynamic post-translational modification found in multicellular eukaryotes.
O-glycans that are terminated or modified with sialic acid residues, which can be recognized by carbohydrate recognition domains in certain proteins and play roles in cell attachment.

An O-linked glycan class initiated in the ER by transfer of mannose to Ser/Thr (via POMT1/2 using dolichol-P-mannose), forming three mammalian cores—M1 (β1-2GlcNAc by POMGNT1), M2 (additional β1-6GlcNAc branch, often by MGAT5B), and M3 (β1-4GlcNAc by POMGNT2 then β1-3GalNAc by B3GALNT2)—that can be further elongated and capped (e.g., Gal, Fuc, GlcA, sialic acid). These glycans occur on many proteins, prominently α-dystroglycan (M3 so far unique to this protein), where they mediate ECM interactions; defects in O-mannosylation cause secondary dystroglycanopathies and are linked to infection and cancer.

O-mannose glycans are a class of O-glycans initiated by the attachment of mannose to serine or threonine residues of proteins. Found in mammals, yeast, and other organisms, these glycans can be extended into several core structures, such as core M1 and M2. They play important roles in protein function, cell signaling, and act as receptors for viruses and extracellular matrix proteins. In mammals, O-mannose glycans are especially abundant in the brain and on α-dystroglycan, with defects in their biosynthesis linked to congenital muscular dystrophies.
A disaccharide motif in which fucose is α1-3 linked to N-acetylglucosamine. This structure is commonly found on the outer branches of N-glycan chains and plays a role in glycan degradation pathways.

A glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chain that is covalently attached to a core protein through an O-linked xylose residue. This structure includes dermatan sulfate (DS), chondroitin sulfate (CS), and heparan sulfate (HS), all of which share a common core tetrasaccharide linkage region.
The P1 antigen is a specific glycan structure expressed on the urothelium, where it facilitates bacterial attachment and infection.

Paucimannose N-glycans are a class of truncated N-linked glycans characterized by a chitobiose core (GlcNAc2) and a reduced number of mannose residues, typically two or three, but sometimes up to five (e.g., Man2–5GlcNAc2). These structures often lack sialic acids and other anionic groups, and may be modified by core α1-6-fucosylation or other substitutions. Paucimannose N-glycans arise from extensive trimming of high-mannose N-glycans during glycan processing, involving the action of Golgi β-hexosaminidases and α-mannosidase, resulting in shorter glycan chains compared to complex or oligomannose N-glycans. They are commonly found in insects, plants, some invertebrates, and occasionally in mammals.

P blood group antigens are glycan structures, specifically glycosphingolipids, present on red blood cells. They serve as targets for specific antibodies, influencing blood group compatibility, and also act as receptors for certain bacterial adhesins, playing a role in susceptibility to urinary tract infections.

Pectin is a structurally complex class of plant cell wall polysaccharides that are rich in 1-4-linked α-D-galacturonic acid (GalpA). It is primarily found in the primary cell walls of dicots, gymnosperms, and nongraminaceous monocots.
Phosphomannan refers to polysaccharides composed of mannose residues with phosphate groups, commonly found in fungal cell walls.
Phosphopeptidomannan refers to immunogenic mannans that contain both phosphate and peptide groups, typically found in yeast cell walls.
Glycan motifs characterized by multiple fucose residues attached as branches, frequently observed in schistosome glycoconjugates and associated with antigenic determinants like Lewisx and LacdiNAc.

Polyglycosylceramides are a class of glycolipids, also known as macroglycolipids, characterized by long glycan chains—often containing poly-N-acetyllactosamine—attached to a ceramide lipid anchor. These molecules can carry blood group antigens such as A, B, and H.
A glycan motif composed of repeating lacto-N-biose units (Galβ1-3GlcNAcβ1-3)n, commonly found as side chains on certain glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, especially in protozoan parasites.
A polymannose has a backbone composed of repeating α1-6 linked mannose residues, characteristic of yeast N-glycans and forming the core of large polymannosyl structures.
A class of N-glycans found in yeast, characterized by large polymannosyl chains built on a poly(Manα1-6)n backbone.

Poly-N-acetylglucosamine is a bacterial exopolysaccharide composed of β1-6 linked N-acetylglucosamine residues. It is widely distributed among both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria and plays a significant role in biofilm formation and immune evasion.

Poly-N-acetyllactosamine (poly-LN) refers to a linear or branched glycan motif composed of repeating disaccharide units of galactose β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine β1-3, denoted as (Galβ1-4GlcNAcβ1-3)n. These chains are commonly found on N- and O-glycans as well as glycolipids, where they can be further modified with sialic acid and fucose. Poly-N-acetyllactosamine structures serve as scaffolds for terminal glycan modifications and are recognized by galectins.

Polysaccharide A (PSA) is a capsular polysaccharide characterized by zwitterionic properties. It is notable for its immunomodulatory role and its involvement in the maturation of the immune system. Polysaccharide A is distinct from polysialic acids.

Polysialic acid (polySia) is a linear homopolymer of sialic acid (N-acetylneuraminic acid, Neu5Ac) residues, typically linked via α2-8 or α2-9 glycosidic bonds. These chains are commonly found on glycoproteins such as neural cell adhesion molecules (NCAM) and play important roles in vertebrate brain development, neural cell migration, and immune modulation.

Pseudomurein is a glycan-based polymer present in the cell walls of certain methanogenic Archaea. It consists of glycan strands cross-linked by peptides composed of L-amino acids, and is structurally distinct from the peptidoglycan found in bacterial cell walls.
Raffinose is part of a class of plant oligosaccharides, including stachyose and verbascose, which are water-soluble carbohydrates commonly found throughout the plant kingdom.
Rhamnogalacturonan II (RG-II) is a complex pectic polysaccharide domain present in plant cell walls, typically existing as a dimer cross-linked by a borate ester.

Rhamnogalacturonan I (RG-I) is a pectic polysaccharide characterized by a backbone of repeating disaccharide units composed of 4-α-D-galacturonic acid (GalpA) and 2-α-L-rhamnose (Rhap). It is a structural domain of pectin and can contain various side chains, such as arabinogalactan.

Rhamnogalacturonan is a class of pectic polysaccharides found in plant cell walls, characterized by a backbone composed of rhamnose and galacturonic acid residues, and often featuring diverse oligosaccharide side chains.
Rhamnomannan is a complex polysaccharide found in fungal cell walls, composed of rhamnose and mannose residues.
A glycopeptide motif in which N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is α-linked to the amino acid arginine. This structure is found in certain bacterial virulence factors.

The Sda antigen is a glycan motif defined by the terminal structure GalNAcβ1-4(Neu5Acα2-3)Galβ1-, which is recognized by specific monoclonal antibodies and found on certain glycoproteins and glycolipids.
Glycolipids that are modified with both sialic acid and fucose residues, which are implicated in leukocyte adhesion and inflammatory responses.
Polymers composed of repeating sialoglycan units, which can interact with Siglec receptors and modulate immune cell functions such as apoptosis.

Sialoglycans are glycans (oligosaccharides or polysaccharides) that contain one or more sialic acid residues, typically as terminal (outermost) sugars on structures such as N-glycans, O-glycans, glycosphingolipids, milk oligosaccharides, or glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors. These molecules play important roles in cell recognition, immune modulation, and interactions with pathogens.

Sialoglycolipids are glycolipids that contain one or more sialic acid residues. Examples include gangliosides, which are abundant in neural tissues and play important roles in cell recognition and signaling.

A type of N-linked glycan characterized by a core structure with two antennae (biantennary), each ending with sialic acid residues. These glycans are commonly found on human glycoproteins, including therapeutic proteins such as erythropoietin.
Glycolipids that contain sialic acid residues, which are recognized by myelin-associated glycoprotein and play a role in the inhibition of neuronal sprouting.

Sialylated glycosphingolipids are glycosphingolipids that contain sialic acid residues. They are widely distributed in animal families, with the exception of arthropods, and are also referred to as gangliosides.

Sialylated N-acetyllactosamine refers to N-acetyllactosamine disaccharides that have a terminal sialic acid residue. These structures are found in bacterial capsules and serve as targets for certain antibodies.

Sialylated N-glycans are N-linked glycans that possess terminal sialic acid residues. These structures are commonly found on glycoproteins, such as the IgG Fc domain, and play important roles in modulating antibody effector functions and other biological processes.

O-linked glycans that are initiated by N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) and further modified by the addition of sialic acid residues, typically through the action of α2-3 sialyltransferases such as ST3GAL1.
Sialylated O-glycans are O-linked glycans that possess terminal sialic acid residues. These structures can be biosynthesized in engineered yeast expressing human sialyltransferases.

Sialyl Lewis a (sLea) is a tetrasaccharide glycan motif with the structure Neu5Acα2-3Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAc. It serves as a binding determinant for E-selectin and is recognized as a biomarker in cancer diagnostics, notably detected by the CA19-9 assay.

A tumor-associated carbohydrate antigen identical to the sialyl Lewis a (sLeᵃ) tetrasaccharide [Neu5Acα2-3Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAc]. It functions as an E-selectin ligand and serves as the principal serum biomarker for pancreatic and gastrointestinal adenocarcinomas, where it is widely used for diagnostic and prognostic purposes.

Sialyl Lewis x (sLex) is a tetrasaccharide glycan motif with the structure Neu5Acα2-3Galβ1-4(Fucα1-3)GlcNAc. It is a well-known selectin ligand involved in cell adhesion, particularly mediating leukocyte rolling, trafficking, and extravasation during inflammation and immune responses. sLex can be found as a terminal cap on both N- and O-glycans, including core 2 O-glycans, and is used as a biomarker in various biological and pathological processes such as hematopoiesis and leukemogenesis.

Sialyl-Tn is a truncated O-glycan structure (Neu5Acα2-6GalNAcα-) formed by the sialylation of the Tn antigen. It is commonly overexpressed in various cancers and serves as a notable cancer-associated glycan epitope.

The Sialyl-Tn antigen is a glycan structure composed of N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac) linked in an α2-6 configuration to N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) in α configuration. It is recognized as a tumor-associated carbohydrate antigen.

A trisaccharide glycan structure where sialic acid (Sia) is α2-3 linked to galactose (Gal), which is β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc). This structure can be formed by elongation of O-GlcNAc with β1,4Gal followed by sialylation.

A trisaccharide glycan structure consisting of sialic acid (Sia) α2-6 linked to galactose (Gal), which is β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc). This motif is recognized by CD22 on B lymphocytes.

A glucose residue attached through a sulfur atom (S-glycosidic bond) rather than the usual oxygen linkage. This type of linkage is found in compounds such as glucosinolates and can be released by the action of myrosinase.
SSEA-4 is a glycosphingolipid (ganglioside) known as stage-specific embryonic antigen-4, which serves as a marker for embryonic stem cells and cancer stem cells.
Starch is a storage polysaccharide in plants composed of glucose units, typically arranged in insoluble, semicrystalline granules found within chloroplasts or amyloplasts.
A class of sulfated polysaccharides composed mainly of galactose residues, such as agarose and carrageenan, commonly found in red seaweeds.
Glycans that contain sulfated glucuronic acid residues, such as those found in the HNK-1 epitope, which is recognized by specific monoclonal antibodies.

Sulfated glycans are glycans that contain sulfate groups. This category includes a variety of structures, such as those recognized by L-selectin, the HNK-1 epitope, and pituitary glycoprotein hormones.

Sulfated glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are a class of linear polysaccharides that include heparan sulfate, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, and keratan sulfate. These molecules are characterized by the presence of sulfate groups and are typically covalently attached to core proteins in proteoglycans. They play important roles in cell signaling, extracellular matrix structure, and protein interactions.
N-glycans that are modified by the addition of sulfate groups, as seen in structures present on pituitary gonadotropin hormones and in keratan sulfate.
O-glycans of the mucin type that are modified by sulfation, and have been detected in species such as Drosophila and mosquito.

Terminal N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues that are β-linked and sulfated. These motifs are found on pituitary glycoprotein hormones such as lutropin (LH) and thyrotropin (TSH), where they play a role in the structure and function of these glycoproteins.
A glycosphingolipid composed of a galactosylceramide (GalCer) molecule with a sulfate group attached, commonly found in myelin and various other tissues.

The T antigen is a disaccharide glycan structure consisting of galactose (Gal) β1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) O-linked to serine or threonine, representing the core 1 structure of mucin-type O-glycans. It is commonly found as a core 1 O-glycan on glycoproteins, recognized by certain lectins, and is associated with tumor cells.
Teichoic acids are polymers composed of repeating glycerol or ribitol phosphate units joined by phosphodiester linkages, and are found in the cell wall of Gram-positive bacteria.
A glycan structure featuring a fucose residue at the non-reducing terminus of glycan chains, as found in H and Lewis antigens. These terminal fucose residues can be cleaved by fucosidases.
A galactose residue located at the non-reducing end of a glycan, often exposed after the removal of terminal sialic acids. This structural feature can influence glycan recognition and function.
Glucuronic acid residues present at the non-reducing end of glycan chains, commonly observed in certain N-glycans.
Mannose residues located at the non-reducing end of glycan chains, which are important for recognition by mannose receptors.
N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues located at the non-reducing end of glycan chains, commonly present on certain N-glycans and recognized by specific lectins and receptors.

A glycan feature where N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is present at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. This terminal GlcNAc can serve as an acceptor for galactosyltransferases and is recognized by certain lectins, playing a role in glycan recognition and modification.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of sialic acid (Sia) residues at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. These terminal sialic acids can be removed by mild acid treatment or further modified, and their removal exposes the underlying sugar residues.

A glycan feature where a mannose residue is present at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain, linked via an α1-6 glycosidic bond. This terminal α1-6 mannose is important for recognition by specific endoplasmic reticulum lectins and plays a role in ER-associated degradation pathways.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of an α-linked fucose residue at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. This structural motif is recognized by certain lectins and adhesion molecules, playing important roles in molecular recognition and cell signaling.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of α-linked galactose at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. The occurrence or absence of terminal α-galactose can be used to distinguish glycan types among different species or cell lines.
A glycan feature where α-linked mannose is present at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain; this motif is recognized by certain lectins and adhesion molecules.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of β-linked galactose at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. This terminal structure can serve as a substrate for sialylation or be recognized by specific lectins.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain in a β-linkage. This terminal structure is recognized by specific lectins and receptors, including the asialoglycoprotein receptor and the AMR.

A tetraantennary N-glycan is an N-linked glycan structure characterized by four antennae (branches) extending from the core. These branches often terminate in β-linked galactose (Gal) or N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues and are frequently associated with increased sialylation. Tetra-antennary N-glycans are notable for their enhanced biological activity, such as in erythropoietin (EPO), and can exhibit high-affinity binding to certain receptors, including the rat AMR.

The Tn antigen is a single N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residue O-linked to serine or threonine on proteins. It represents the simplest O-GalNAc glycan structure and is the initial product of mucin-type O-glycosylation.
A glycolipid composed of a trehalose disaccharide esterified at both 6-positions with mycolic acids. It serves as a key virulence factor in Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium bovis.

A triantennary N-glycan is an N-linked glycan structure featuring three antennae (branches) extending from the core. These branches often terminate in β-linked galactose (Gal) or N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues. Triantennary N-glycans are recognized for their high-affinity binding to the rat asialoglycoprotein receptor (AMR).
A glycan composed of three mannose residues, found as a modification on intracellular proteins in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

Truncated core 1 O-glycans are O-glycans based on the core 1 structure (Galβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr) that are incompletely extended. Examples include the Tn antigen (GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr) and the T antigen (Galβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr), which represent early intermediates or incomplete forms of core 1 O-glycans.

Truncated N-glycans are N-linked glycans that are incompletely processed, often due to prolonged retention in the endoplasmic reticulum, resulting in shorter glycan chains than typically found in mature N-glycans.
O-glycans initiated by GalNAc on serine or threonine residues that are incompletely extended, including structures such as Tn, STn, and T antigens, which are often associated with cancer.

Truncated O-glycans are O-linked glycans that are not fully elongated or processed, often terminating in early core structures such as Tn antigen, T antigen, or their sialylated forms (STn, ST). These incompletely extended glycans frequently expose core structures and are commonly observed in carcinomas, where they can evoke immune responses.

A disaccharide motif consisting of galactose β1-3 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (Galβ1-3GlcNAc), known as the Type 1 chain. This structure can be repeated, serves as a scaffold for further glycan extension, and acts as a precursor for type 1 H and Lewis antigens.

The type-2 unit is a disaccharide motif consisting of galactose β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (Galβ1-4GlcNAc), which can be repeated and serves as a scaffold for further glycan extension. It acts as a minimal acceptor for glycosyltransferases, is a ligand for galectins, and forms the backbone for the synthesis of blood group H, A, B, and Lewis antigens.
A glycan chain present in human erythrocyte glycolipids that serves as the backbone for A, B, and H blood group determinants.

Xylan is a class of hemicellulosic polysaccharides composed mainly of linear β1-4-linked D-xylose residues. Commonly found in plant cell walls, especially in secondary cell walls, xylans may be substituted with other sugars or chemical groups and are important structural components in plants.

Xylogalacturonan is a class of plant cell wall pectic polysaccharides characterized by a homogalacturonan backbone with single β-D-xylose residues attached to the O-3 position of some galacturonic acid residues.

Xyloglucan is a major hemicellulosic polysaccharide found in plant cell walls, consisting of a β-1,4-glucan backbone substituted with α-D-xylose and sometimes other sugars. It plays a key role in cell wall structure and expansion by acting as a tether between cellulose microfibrils. Oligosaccharide fragments derived from the enzymatic or chemical breakdown of xyloglucan can trigger defense responses in plants and provide protection against pathogens.
Xylosides are glycosides in which xylose serves as the sugar moiety. They are used experimentally to prime the synthesis and secretion of glycosaminoglycan chains in cells.
Xylosylated glycans are glycans that contain xylose residues. These glycans may be attached to glycoproteins or glycolipids and are found in various organisms, including parasites.
A terminal N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residue linked via an alpha(1-3) glycosidic bond, as found in the A blood group antigen tetrasaccharide.
Branches in glycogen that consist of glucose units connected by α(1–6) glycosidic bonds, appearing periodically along the main α(1–4)-linked glucose chain.
A sialic acid residue linked in an α2-3 configuration that is present as part of a branched glycan structure, such as found on ganglioside GM2.
A disaccharide motif consisting of sialic acid linked α2-3 to lactosamine (Galβ1-4GlcNAc), commonly found in glycoproteins and glycolipids, and produced by group B streptococci.

The α-Gal epitope is a glycan determinant composed of galactose in an α-linkage. It is notably absent in humans and Old World primates, which results in the production of anti-α-Gal antibodies in these species.
A mannose residue attached through an alpha glycosidic bond, frequently found in diverse glycan structures and recognized by mannose-binding proteins.

A post-translational modification in which a fucose residue is attached through an alpha linkage to the oxygen atom of serine or threonine residues, most commonly found on epidermal growth factor (EGF) repeats.
A polymer of glucose residues linked by alpha glycosidic bonds, forming nanofilaments such as those observed in the mitochondrial dividing ring of certain algae.
A polysaccharide composed of a backbone of α1-6-linked mannose residues with α1-2-linked mannose side chains.
A glycan structure that contains at least one α-linked mannose residue, which is recognized as a pathogen-associated molecular pattern (PAMP) by immune receptors.
A glycosidic linkage where sialic acid is attached to another sugar through an alpha configuration.

β-(1,3)-glucan is a polysaccharide composed of glucose units linked by β-(1,3) glycosidic bonds. It can be linear or branched and is a major structural component of fungal and oomycete cell walls. β-(1,3)-glucan can also be released as oligosaccharides, which may function as pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) in plants.

A polysaccharide composed of glucose residues linked by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds; it is the main structural component of cellulose in plant cell walls. Oligosaccharides released from cellulose can act as signaling molecules in plants.

A polysaccharide or oligosaccharide unit composed of mannuronic acid residues linked by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds; these structures form part of alginate, a major component of some bacterial and algal extracellular matrices.
A homopolymer of mannose residues linked via β1-2 glycosidic bonds, characteristic of the mannogen polysaccharide produced by Leishmania parasites.

A structural motif where N-acetylglucosamine is linked via a beta-1,2-glycosidic bond, commonly found on the α1-3-mannose arm of N-glycans and known to influence fucosyltransferase substrate specificity.

A structural motif in which N-acetylgalactosamine is attached through a beta-1,4-glycosidic bond. This linkage is recognized as an antennal modification on N-glycans, such as those found in sea urchins.
A structural motif in which N-acetylglucosamine is attached via a beta-1,4-glycosidic bond, typically to mannose on N-glycans, forming the characteristic bisecting GlcNAc feature.

A β(1-6)-linked N-acetylglucosamine residue that is transferred by core 2 β1-6GlcNAcT enzymes (CGNT1, 3, and 4) during the biosynthesis of core 2 O-GalNAc glycans. This residue often serves as the branching point for poly-LacNAc extensions in mucin glycoproteins.
A glycoside in which a β-D-xylose residue is linked to an aglycone. β-D-xylosides can alter proteoglycan biosynthesis by serving as artificial primers for glycosaminoglycan chain initiation.

β-glucan refers to a class of polysaccharides made up of glucose monomers connected mainly by β-glycosidic bonds. These molecules are commonly found in the cell walls of fungi and plants, and they can exhibit structural diversity, including linear or mixed-linkage forms such as β-1,3 and β-1,4 linkages.
A galactose residue attached to another sugar or molecule via a β-glycosidic bond; commonly found as a terminal or internal residue in glycans recognized by galectins and other lectins.

A residue of 3-deoxy-D-manno-oct-2-ulosonic acid (Kdo) linked via a β-glycosidic bond, commonly found in the oligosaccharide portion of bacterial glycolipids, such as those present in E. coli capsular polysaccharides.

A glycan structure featuring an N-acetylgalactosamine residue linked through a beta-glycosidic bond. These structures can serve as primers for oligosaccharide chains on mucins and are known to inhibit O-glycosylation of glycoproteins.
A glycan structure containing an N-acetylglucosamine residue linked via a beta-glycosidic bond; it is found as an active glycoside in various oligosaccharides.
